keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject

byline.original: By MARK MAZZETTI and ERIC SCHMITT
byline.contributor: Matt Apuzzo and Scott Shane contributed reporting.

lead_paragraph: An American once considered a possible target to be killed in Pakistan is in custody in the United States, bolstering an argument that it is feasible to capture terrorism suspects, even in remote parts of the world.

headline.print_headline: U.S. Considered Killing a Citizen Now Facing Trial
headline.main: Terrorism Case Renews Debate Over Drone Hits

snippet: An American once considered a possible target to be killed in Pakistan is in custody in the United States, bolstering an argument that it is feasible to capture terrorism suspects, even in remote parts of the world.
abstract: Arraignment of Texas-born suspected Al Qaeda operative Mohanad Mahmoud Al Farekh on terrorism charges follows prolonged manhunt and intense debate over whether he should have been targeted by drone strike in Pakistan; Farekh would have become second American citizen targeted overseas without trial; case bolsters argument that capturing militant suspects is both more feasible and more valuable than killing them.
